Executive Summary
This document was developed and revised to comply with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agencys (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) II, under Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act amendments of 1990, 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68. Figure ES-1 provides an outline of the RMP. Chlorine system processes are covered under this regulation at the City of Cedar Park water treatment plant (WTP). 

Figure ES-1. Risk Management Plan Outline

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN

This document contains information on the chlorine system relevant to the regulation requirements. The technical information herein may be used as a training reference in initial and recurring operator and maintenance training. Training on process fundamentals, operations, and maintenance, coupled with the recommended process modifications discussed below, will reduce the potential hazards to WTP personnel and the surrounding community.
An emergency response program (ERP) and an incident investigation program are included. These two programs should be an integral part of both initial and recurring training.
A risk management plan (Plan), as required by the EPA, is included at the end of the main body of this document. It consists of a summary of data elements that must be submitted to the EPA, which eventually will be uploaded onto a public-access database. The Plan has an executive summary that follows a required EPA format and is intended to inform the public of the WTPs proactive stance toward protection of the environment and the surrounding community. 

Hazard Assessment
The hazard assessment comprises a worst-case and alternative release scenario (ARS) each for the chlorine system, as

well as a 5-year accident history for the same. The hazard assessment was conducted as an initial screening procedure as part of determining into which program level (I, II, or III) the WTP falls.
Residences lie within the EPA-defined endpoint concentrations of WTPs worst-case releases. Therefore, the WTP is ineligible for Program Level I. Because Texas public utilities are currently excluded from Program Level III, the WTP is included in Program Level II. Section 1 includes the hazard assessment.

Worst-Case Scenario
The worst-case scenario was defined as a 1-ton container (2,000 pounds) of chlorine gas experiencing a release of the total quantity of gas within 10 minutes due to a catastrophic event. A mitigation factor of 0.55 was allowed for this evaluation because the enclosure covering the chlorine tank is considered a passive mitigation measure. This scenario was modeled using the EPA-approved RMP*Comp program. The toxic endpoint for chlorine was determined to be 0.9 miles.

Alternative Release Scenario
The ARS of chlorine was also modeled using RMP*Comp. Source term estimation of approximately 175 pounds released was derived from a scenario of pressurized flexible tubing failure. The RMP*Comp program estimated the 3 parts per million (ppm) chlorine footprint to extend to 0.1 mile.

5-Year Accident History
No accidents have occurred at the WTP involving either on-site or off-site consequences within the last five years.

Management Program
The management program consists of the document management system described subsequently.

Document Management System
A document management system was established to attribute responsibility for the development, implementation, and maintenance of the RMP. The RMP must be updated every 3 years, or any time a covered process undergoes a physical or administrative modification. The document management system is largely a function of the RMP team (Table ES-1).

Table ES-1. Cedar Park Water Treatment Plant Risk Management Progr

Position/Expertise
WTP Superintendent
Operators

Risk Management Program Team
The following members are responsible for the RMP development, implementation, and maintenance. The WTP superintendent has the ultimate responsibility.

Prevention Program
The prevention program is more appropriately entitled the accidental release prevention program. It comprises safety information, hazard review, operating procedures, training, maintenance, incident investigation, and compliance audit procedures. Each has an entire section devoted to it in this Risk Management Plan (Plan).

Safety Information
Safety information is divided between chemical safety information and process safety information.

Chemical Safety Information
Comprehensive chemical data are provided in this section to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazards, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of each regulated substance. This information was compiled from numerous sources and is intended to be a one-stop source for the reader seeking data on these substances. The physical data will provide useful information in the inevitable event the WTP processes are modified, thereby requiring revisited dense gas dispersion modeling.

Process Safety Information
Process safety information was meticulously compiled on each system studied. Specifications are collocated in one place for easy reference. This section details maximum intended inventory, safe upper and lower temperatures, safe upper and lower pressures, and codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the process. Used as a training reference together with the process schematics located in Appendix A, the reader will readily understand the function and operation of the chlorine system.

Hazard Review
A hazard review was conducted for the chlorine system on April 26, 19

99, and updated on September 26, 2023. The team consisted of facility management, process operating and maintenance experts, outside process design engineers, and consultants knowledgeable in the hazard review process itself. The hazard review technique used was a hybrid hazard and operability study (HAZOP), in the form of a What If analysis. The What If was developed from HAZOP experience at similar treatment facilities.

Recommendations
The result of the hazard review is a set of recommendations for the WTP to implement. The rule under 40 CFR 68.50 requires the City of Cedar Park to ensure that problems identified are resolved in a timely manner. For those items that cannot be resolved promptly, it is recommended that a schedule be developed that addresses those issues, with personnel responsibility assigned for each item. 
The hazard review team, with consensus from all team members, developed the WTP recommendations. Table ES-2 provides a summary of the recommendations and the results of the hazard review. The table also includes recommendations made during subsequent meetings of City staff, as described in the following sections.

Table ES-2. Summary of Hazard Review Recommendations
Administrative and Operational
Conduct vendor audits to verify quality assurance and quality control.
Supervise the chlorine supplier and conduct visual inspections.
Ensure lines are evacuated before disconnection.
Share WTP weather station information.
Training
Verify training of WTP operating and maintenance procedures.
Ensure operators understand the hazards associated with exposing reactive, unapproved substances to the chlorination system.
Use good housekeeping.
Ensure that the Citys emergency response policy is implemented, and the staff is properly trained.
Further Study
Evaluate on-site chlorine generation.

Operating Procedures
Chlorination system operating procedures have been amended for the WTP. They provide system descriptions, specifications, and operating proce

dures for the chlorine system. 
Procedures include initial startup; normal, temporary, abnormal, emergency shutdowns, and operations; startup following a shutdown or major change; and consequences of deviation. Also included are troubleshooting procedures.

Training
EPA requires training to be included in the RMP. A program has been developed with guidelines on how to conduct regular and structured WTP training. Training record forms (Exhibit 3-1) are included with the Plan for the required training documentation. Additionally, a training record has been compiled and included for all affected personnel associated with the covered processes.

Maintenance
A maintenance program has been developed with associated documentation forms. Preventive maintenance will reduce potential hazards to personnel on-site, as well as to the off-site public. Documentation and recordkeeping associated with the maintenance program must be provided to state and federal regulators upon request during inspections. 

Incident Investigation
The WTP has developed an incident investigation program that adheres to EPAs established strict guidelines to follow in the aftermath of any release involving the chlorine system. The incident investigation program outlines key milestones that must be accomplished within 24 hours of any covered incident and the actions that must subsequently occur. The facility should use lessons learned from the incident and take actions needed to prevent similar incidents in the future. Exhibit 3-2 includes incident investigation report forms, which must be maintained for a minimum of 5 years after each incident.

Compliance Audits
Internal compliance audits must be conducted every 3 years to verify compliance with the programs and procedures contained in this document. The WTP superintendent must certify that the RMP team has evaluated compliance with the provisions of the RMP and verify that the procedures and practices are adequate and are being followed. Exhibit 3-3

provides the audit report forms, the two most recent of which must always be maintained on-site and available for review by state or federal regulators upon request.

Emergency Response Program
The ERP is included as part of the RMP if a significant release ever occurs. As in all the aforementioned programs, it is important to review this program regularly. The 40 CFR 68.95 rule requires training for all employees in relevant procedures of the ERP.
It is recommended that training on the specific WTP procedures take place upon initial employment and every 3 years thereafter, as with most of the other RMP training programs. The ERP provides discussion of other training recommendations, i.e., OSHA 8-, 24-, and 40-hour training, as appropriate to the level of response.

Risk Management Plan
Appendix B provides a copy of the Plan submitted to EPA. As stated previously, this document is public information and will be uploaded on a public-access database. No other part of the WTPs Plan will be made available to the public. 

Summary of Action Items for the City of Cedar Park
1.	Record details of all accidental releases, according to the RMP rule, 40 CFR 68.42. Refer to Section 1.3 for format details. 
2.	Update the document management system when there are personnel or administrative changes that affect the lines of authority or responsibility for maintaining the RMP at the WTP (RMP rule, 40 CFR 68.15). Section 2.1 provides format details.
3.	Train and test all employees operating a process for competency of operating procedures. Section 3.3 provides the operating procedures for the WTP. Alternatively, the City of Cedar Park may certify in writing that the employee has the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the duties and responsibilities as provided in the operating procedures (RMP rule, 40 CFR 68.54). Section 3.4 provides training documentation forms.
4.	Train all employees operating a process on the WTP maintenance procedures provided in Se

ction 3.5. To ensure that the employee can perform the job tasks in a safe manner, each such employee must be trained in the hazards of the process, in how to avoid or correct unsafe conditions, and in the procedures applicable to the employees job tasks (RMP rule, 40 CFR 68.56). Additionally, all maintenance contractors must also be trained to perform any applicable maintenance procedures as provided in each RMP document. Section 3.4 provides training documentation forms.
5.	Refresher training on operating and maintenance procedures must be provided every 3 years. Section 3.4 provides training documentation forms.
6.	Conduct incident investigations no later than 48 hours according to the RMP rule, 40 CFR 68.60, no later than 48 hours following each incident. Section 3.6 provides guidance.
7.	The RMP rule, 40 CFR 68.58, requires the City of Cedar Park to certify compliance with RMP accident prevention program provisions at least every 3 years to verify that the procedures and practices developed under the rule are adequate and are being followed. Section 3.7 provides guidance, along with compliance audit forms.
8.	The rule, 40 CFR 68.95, requires training for all employees in relevant procedures of the ERP. It recommends that training on the specific WTP procedures take place upon initial employment and every 3 years thereafter, as with most of the other RMP training programs. Other training recommendations, i.e., OSHA 8-, 24-, and 40-hour training, are discussed in the ERP as appropriate to the level of response. Section 4 provides discussion of the ERP. Section 3.4 provides training documentation forms.
9.	The City of Cedar Park must submit the risk management plan (Plan) to the appropriate agency by October 2023. The next Plan update would be required in 5 years, or in October 2028. The Plan is a summary of the RMP and will be submitted electronically using EPAs RMP eSubmit software.
